conclusion: Determine the maximum horizontal force F that can be applied to block B such that blocks A and B remain relatively stationary.
Consider the forces acting on both blocks and use the conditions for static and kinetic friction.
Block A is stacked on block B, which is on a horizontal ground. A horizontal force F is applied to block B.
The mass of block A is 1kg and that of block B is 2kg.
The maximum static friction force between A and B is 1 N.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between B and the ground is 0.1.
The normal force NA on block A is equal to its weight, NA = 10 N.
The normal force NB on block B is the sum of the weights of blocks A and B, NB = 30 N.
The kinetic friction force between block B and the ground is f_kin = 3 N.
For A and B to remain stationary, the force F must be such that the frictional force between B and the ground is at least equal to F minus the maximum static friction force between A and B.
The maximum force F that can be applied to B without causing A to slide is F = f_max + f_kin = 4 N.
The condition for keeping A and B relatively stationary is that the force F does not exceed 4 N.
